                              <div class="line">Therefore depart and leave him here with me.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ADRIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">I will not hence and leave my husband here:</div>
                              <div class="line">And ill it doth beseem your holiness</div>
                              <div class="line">To separate the husband and the wife.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEMELIA</div>
                              <div class="line">Be quiet and depart: thou shalt not have him.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>Exit</p>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">LUCIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">Complain unto the duke of this indignity.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ADRIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">Come, go: I will fall prostrate at his feet</div>
                              <div class="line">And never rise until my tears and prayers</div>
                              <div class="line">Have won his grace to come in person hither</div>
                              <div class="line">And take perforce my husband from the abbess.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">Second Merchant</div>
                              <div class="line">By this, I think, the dial points at five:</div>
                              <div class="line">Anon, I'm sure, the duke himself in person</div>
                              <div class="line">Comes this way to the melancholy vale,</div>
                              <div class="line">The place of death and sorry execution,</div>
                              <div class="line">Behind the ditches of the abbey here.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANGELO</div>
                              <div class="line">Upon what cause?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">Second Merchant</div>
                              <div class="line">To see a reverend Syracusian merchant,</div>
                              <div class="line">Who put unluckily into this bay</div>
                              <div class="line">Against the laws and statutes of this town,</div>
                              <div class="line">Beheaded publicly for his offence.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANGELO</div>
                              <div class="line">See where they come: we will behold his death.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">LUCIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">Kneel to the duke before he pass the abbey.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>Enter DUKE SOLINUS, attended; AEGEON bareheaded; with the
Headsman and other Officers</p>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Yet once again proclaim it publicly,</div>
                              <div class="line">If any friend will pay the sum for him,</div>
                              <div class="line">He shall not die; so much we tender him.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ADRIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">Justice, most sacred duke, against the abbess!</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">She is a virtuous and a reverend lady:</div>
                              <div class="line">It cannot be that she hath done thee wrong.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ADRIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">May it please your grace, Antipholus, my husband,</div>
                              <div class="line">Whom I made lord of me and all I had,</div>
                              <div class="line">At your important letters,--this ill day</div>
                              <div class="line">A most outrageous fit of madness took him;</div>
                              <div class="line">That desperately he hurried through the street,</div>
                              <div class="line">With him his bondman, all as mad as he--</div>
                              <div class="line">Doing displeasure to the citizens</div>
                              <div class="line">By rushing in their houses, bearing thence</div>
                              <div class="line">Rings, jewels, any thing his rage did like.</div>
                              <div class="line">Once did I get him bound and sent him home,</div>
                              <div class="line">Whilst to take order for the wrongs I went,</div>
                              <div class="line">That here and there his fury had committed.</div>
                              <div class="line">Anon, I wot not by what strong escape,</div>
                              <div class="line">He broke from those that had the guard of him;</div>
                              <div class="line">And with his mad attendant and himself,</div>
                              <div class="line">Each one with ireful passion, with drawn swords,</div>
                              <div class="line">Met us again and madly bent on us,</div>
                              <div class="line">Chased us away; till, raising of more aid,</div>
                              <div class="line">We came again to bind them. Then they fled</div>
                              <div class="line">Into this abbey, whither we pursued them:</div>
                              <div class="line">And here the abbess shuts the gates on us</div>
                              <div class="line">And will not suffer us to fetch him out,</div>
                              <div class="line">Nor send him forth that we may bear him hence.</div>
                              <div class="line">Therefore, most gracious duke, with thy command</div>
                              <div class="line">Let him be brought forth and borne hence for help.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Long since thy husband served me in my wars,</div>
                              <div class="line">And I to thee engaged a prince's word,</div>
                              <div class="line">When thou didst make him master of thy bed,</div>
                              <div class="line">To do him all the grace and good I could.</div>
                              <div class="line">Go, some of you, knock at the abbey-gate</div>
                              <div class="line">And bid the lady abbess come to me.</div>
                              <div class="line">I will determine this before I stir.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>Enter a Servant</p>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">Servant</div>
                              <div class="line">O mistress, mistress, shift and save yourself!</div>
                              <div class="line">My master and his man are both broke loose,</div>
                              <div class="line">Beaten the maids a-row and bound the doctor</div>
                              <div class="line">Whose beard they have singed off with brands of fire;</div>
                              <div class="line">And ever, as it blazed, they threw on him</div>
                              <div class="line">Great pails of puddled mire to quench the hair:</div>
                              <div class="line">My master preaches patience to him and the while</div>
                              <div class="line">His man with scissors nicks him like a fool,</div>
                              <div class="line">And sure, unless you send some present help,</div>
                              <div class="line">Between them they will kill the conjurer.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ADRIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">Peace, fool! thy master and his man are here,</div>
                              <div class="line">And that is false thou dost report to us.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">Servant</div>
                              <div class="line">Mistress, upon my life, I tell you true;</div>
                              <div class="line">I have not breathed almost since I did see it.</div>
                              <div class="line">He cries for you, and vows, if he can take you,</div>
                              <div class="line">To scorch your face and to disfigure you.</div>
                              <p>Cry within</p>
                              <div class="line">Hark, hark! I hear him, mistress. fly, be gone!</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Come, stand by me; fear nothing. Guard with halberds!</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ADRIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">Ay me, it is my husband! Witness you,</div>
                              <div class="line">That he is borne about invisible:</div>
                              <div class="line">Even now we housed him in the abbey here;</div>
                              <div class="line">And now he's there, past thought of human reason.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus</p>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Justice, most gracious duke, O, grant me justice!</div>
                              <div class="line">Even for the service that long since I did thee,</div>
                              <div class="line">When I bestrid thee in the wars and took</div>
                              <div class="line">Deep scars to save thy life; even for the blood</div>
                              <div class="line">That then I lost for thee, now grant me justice.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEGEON</div>
                              <div class="line">Unless the fear of death doth make me dote,</div>
                              <div class="line">I see my son Antipholus and Dromio.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Justice, sweet prince, against that woman there!</div>
                              <div class="line">She whom thou gavest to me to be my wife,</div>
                              <div class="line">That hath abused and dishonour'd me</div>
                              <div class="line">Even in the strength and height of injury!</div>
                              <div class="line">Beyond imagination is the wrong</div>
                              <div class="line">That she this day hath shameless thrown on me.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Discover how, and thou shalt find me just.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">This day, great duke, she shut the doors upon me,</div>
                              <div class="line">While she with harlots feasted in my house.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">A grievous fault! Say, woman, didst thou so?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ADRIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">No, my good lord: myself, he and my sister</div>
                              <div class="line">To-day did dine together. So befall my soul</div>
                              <div class="line">As this is false he burdens me withal!</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">LUCIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">Ne'er may I look on day, nor sleep on night,</div>
                              <div class="line">But she tells to your highness simple truth!</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANGELO</div>
                              <div class="line">O perjured woman! They are both forsworn:</div>
                              <div class="line">In this the madman justly chargeth them.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">My liege, I am advised what I say,</div>
                              <div class="line">Neither disturbed with the effect of wine,</div>
                              <div class="line">Nor heady-rash, provoked with raging ire,</div>
                              <div class="line">Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad.</div>
                              <div class="line">This woman lock'd me out this day from dinner:</div>
                              <div class="line">That goldsmith there, were he not pack'd with her,</div>
                              <div class="line">Could witness it, for he was with me then;</div>
                              <div class="line">Who parted with me to go fetch a chain,</div>
                              <div class="line">Promising to bring it to the Porpentine,</div>
                              <div class="line">Where Balthazar and I did dine together.</div>
                              <div class="line">Our dinner done, and he not coming thither,</div>
                              <div class="line">I went to seek him: in the street I met him</div>
                              <div class="line">And in his company that gentleman.</div>
                              <div class="line">There did this perjured goldsmith swear me down</div>
                              <div class="line">That I this day of him received the chain,</div>
                              <div class="line">Which, God he knows, I saw not: for the which</div>
                              <div class="line">He did arrest me with an officer.</div>
                              <div class="line">I did obey, and sent my peasant home</div>
                              <div class="line">For certain ducats: he with none return'd</div>
                              <div class="line">Then fairly I bespoke the officer</div>
                              <div class="line">To go in person with me to my house.</div>
                              <div class="line">By the way we met</div>
                              <div class="line">My wife, her sister, and a rabble more</div>
                              <div class="line">Of vile confederates. Along with them</div>
                              <div class="line">They brought one Pinch, a hungry lean-faced villain,</div>
                              <div class="line">A mere anatomy, a mountebank,</div>
                              <div class="line">A threadbare juggler and a fortune-teller,</div>
                              <div class="line">A needy, hollow-eyed, sharp-looking wretch,</div>
                              <div class="line">A dead-looking man: this pernicious slave,</div>
                              <div class="line">Forsooth, took on him as a conjurer,</div>
                              <div class="line">And, gazing in mine eyes, feeling my pulse,</div>
                              <div class="line">And with no face, as 'twere, outfacing me,</div>
                              <div class="line">Cries out, I was possess'd. Then all together</div>
                              <div class="line">They fell upon me, bound me, bore me thence</div>
                              <div class="line">And in a dark and dankish vault at home</div>
                              <div class="line">There left me and my man, both bound together;</div>
                              <div class="line">Till, gnawing with my teeth my bonds in sunder,</div>
                              <div class="line">I gain'd my freedom, and immediately</div>
                              <div class="line">Ran hither to your grace; whom I beseech</div>
                              <div class="line">To give me ample satisfaction</div>
                              <div class="line">For these deep shames and great indignities.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANGELO</div>
                              <div class="line">My lord, in truth, thus far I witness with him,</div>
                              <div class="line">That he dined not at home, but was lock'd out.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">But had he such a chain of thee or no?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANGELO</div>
                              <div class="line">He had, my lord: and when he ran in here,</div>
                              <div class="line">These people saw the chain about his neck.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">Second Merchant</div>
                              <div class="line">Besides, I will be sworn these ears of mine</div>
                              <div class="line">Heard you confess you had the chain of him</div>
                              <div class="line">After you first forswore it on the mart:</div>
                              <div class="line">And thereupon I drew my sword on you;</div>
                              <div class="line">And then you fled into this abbey here,</div>
                              <div class="line">From whence, I think, you are come by miracle.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">I never came within these abbey-walls,</div>
                              <div class="line">Nor ever didst thou draw thy sword on me:</div>
                              <div class="line">I never saw the chain, so help me Heaven!</div>
                              <div class="line">And this is false you burden me withal.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Why, what an intricate impeach is this!</div>
                              <div class="line">I think you all have drunk of Circe's cup.</div>
                              <div class="line">If here you housed him, here he would have been;</div>
                              <div class="line">If he were mad, he would not plead so coldly:</div>
                              <div class="line">You say he dined at home; the goldsmith here</div>
                              <div class="line">Denies that saying. Sirrah, what say you?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Sir, he dined with her there, at the Porpentine.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">Courtezan</div>
                              <div class="line">He did, and from my finger snatch'd that ring.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">'Tis true, my liege; this ring I had of her.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Saw'st thou him enter at the abbey here?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">Courtezan</div>
                              <div class="line">As sure, my liege, as I do see your grace.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Why, this is strange. Go call the abbess hither.</div>
                              <div class="line">I think you are all mated or stark mad.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>Exit one to Abbess</p>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEGEON</div>
                              <div class="line">Most mighty duke, vouchsafe me speak a word:</div>
                              <div class="line">Haply I see a friend will save my life</div>
                              <div class="line">And pay the sum that may deliver me.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Speak freely, Syracusian, what thou wilt.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEGEON</div>
                              <div class="line">Is not your name, sir, call'd Antipholus?</div>
                              <div class="line">And is not that your bondman, Dromio?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Within this hour I was his bondman sir,</div>
                              <div class="line">But he, I thank him, gnaw'd in two my cords:</div>
                              <div class="line">Now am I Dromio and his man unbound.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEGEON</div>
                              <div class="line">I am sure you both of you remember me.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Ourselves we do remember, sir, by you;</div>
                              <div class="line">For lately we were bound, as you are now</div>
                              <div class="line">You are not Pinch's patient, are you, sir?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEGEON</div>
                              <div class="line">Why look you strange on me? you know me well.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEGEON</div>
                              <div class="line">O, grief hath changed me since you saw me last,</div>
                              <div class="line">And careful hours with time's deformed hand</div>
                              <div class="line">Have written strange defeatures in my face:</div>
                              <div class="line">But tell me yet, dost thou not know my voice?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Neither.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEGEON</div>
                              <div class="line">Dromio, nor thou?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">No, trust me, sir, nor I.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEGEON</div>
                              <div class="line">I am sure thou dost.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Ay, sir, but I am sure I do not; and whatsoever a</div>
                              <div class="line">man denies, you are now bound to believe him.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEGEON</div>
                              <div class="line">Not know my voice! O time's extremity,</div>
                              <div class="line">Hast thou so crack'd and splitted my poor tongue</div>
                              <div class="line">In seven short years, that here my only son</div>
                              <div class="line">Knows not my feeble key of untuned cares?</div>
                              <div class="line">Though now this grained face of mine be hid</div>
                              <div class="line">In sap-consuming winter's drizzled snow,</div>
                              <div class="line">And all the conduits of my blood froze up,</div>
                              <div class="line">Yet hath my night of life some memory,</div>
                              <div class="line">My wasting lamps some fading glimmer left,</div>
                              <div class="line">My dull deaf ears a little use to hear:</div>
                              <div class="line">All these old witnesses--I cannot err--</div>
                              <div class="line">Tell me thou art my son Antipholus.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">I never saw my father in my life.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEGEON</div>
                              <div class="line">But seven years since, in Syracusa, boy,</div>
                              <div class="line">Thou know'st we parted: but perhaps, my son,</div>
                              <div class="line">Thou shamest to acknowledge me in misery.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">The duke and all that know me in the city</div>
                              <div class="line">Can witness with me that it is not so</div>
                              <div class="line">I ne'er saw Syracusa in my life.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">I tell thee, Syracusian, twenty years</div>
                              <div class="line">Have I been patron to Antipholus,</div>
                              <div class="line">During which time he ne'er saw Syracusa:</div>
                              <div class="line">I see thy age and dangers make thee dote.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>Re-enter AEMILIA, with ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse and
DROMIO of Syracuse</p>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEMELIA</div>
                              <div class="line">Most mighty duke, behold a man much wrong'd.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>All gather to see them</p>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ADRIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">I see two husbands, or mine eyes deceive me.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">One of these men is Genius to the other;</div>
                              <div class="line">And so of these. Which is the natural man,</div>
                              <div class="line">And which the spirit? who deciphers them?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">I, sir, am Dromio; command him away.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">I, sir, am Dromio; pray, let me stay.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">AEgeon art thou not? or else his ghost?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">O, my old master! who hath bound him here?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEMELIA</div>
                              <div class="line">Whoever bound him, I will loose his bonds</div>
                              <div class="line">And gain a husband by his liberty.</div>
                              <div class="line">Speak, old AEgeon, if thou be'st the man</div>
                              <div class="line">That hadst a wife once call'd AEmilia</div>
                              <div class="line">That bore thee at a burden two fair sons:</div>
                              <div class="line">O, if thou be'st the same AEgeon, speak,</div>
                              <div class="line">And speak unto the same AEmilia!</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEGEON</div>
                              <div class="line">If I dream not, thou art AEmilia:</div>
                              <div class="line">If thou art she, tell me where is that son</div>
                              <div class="line">That floated with thee on the fatal raft?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEMELIA</div>
                              <div class="line">By men of Epidamnum he and I</div>
                              <div class="line">And the twin Dromio all were taken up;</div>
                              <div class="line">But by and by rude fishermen of Corinth</div>
                              <div class="line">By force took Dromio and my son from them</div>
                              <div class="line">And me they left with those of Epidamnum.</div>
                              <div class="line">What then became of them I cannot tell</div>
                              <div class="line">I to this fortune that you see me in.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Why, here begins his morning story right;</div>
                              <div class="line">These two Antipholuses, these two so like,</div>
                              <div class="line">And these two Dromios, one in semblance,--</div>
                              <div class="line">Besides her urging of her wreck at sea,--</div>
                              <div class="line">These are the parents to these children,</div>
                              <div class="line">Which accidentally are met together.</div>
                              <div class="line">Antipholus, thou camest from Corinth first?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">No, sir, not I; I came from Syracuse.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Stay, stand apart; I know not which is which.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">I came from Corinth, my most gracious lord,--</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">And I with him.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Brought to this town by that most famous warrior,</div>
                              <div class="line">Duke Menaphon, your most renowned uncle.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ADRIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">Which of you two did dine with me to-day?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">I, gentle mistress.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ADRIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">And are not you my husband?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">No; I say nay to that.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">And so do I; yet did she call me so:</div>
                              <div class="line">And this fair gentlewoman, her sister here,</div>
                              <div class="line">Did call me brother.</div>
                              <p>To Luciana</p>
                              <div class="line">What I told you then,</div>
                              <div class="line">I hope I shall have leisure to make good;</div>
                              <div class="line">If this be not a dream I see and hear.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANGELO</div>
                              <div class="line">That is the chain, sir, which you had of me.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">I think it be, sir; I deny it not.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">And you, sir, for this chain arrested me.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANGELO</div>
                              <div class="line">I think I did, sir; I deny it not.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ADRIANA</div>
                              <div class="line">I sent you money, sir, to be your bail,</div>
                              <div class="line">By Dromio; but I think he brought it not.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">No, none by me.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">This purse of ducats I received from you,</div>
                              <div class="line">And Dromio, my man, did bring them me.</div>
                              <div class="line">I see we still did meet each other's man,</div>
                              <div class="line">And I was ta'en for him, and he for me,</div>
                              <div class="line">And thereupon these errors are arose.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">These ducats pawn I for my father here.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">It shall not need; thy father hath his life.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">Courtezan</div>
                              <div class="line">Sir, I must have that diamond from you.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">There, take it; and much thanks for my good cheer.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">AEMELIA</div>
                              <div class="line">Renowned duke, vouchsafe to take the pains</div>
                              <div class="line">To go with us into the abbey here</div>
                              <div class="line">And hear at large discoursed all our fortunes:</div>
                              <div class="line">And all that are assembled in this place,</div>
                              <div class="line">That by this sympathized one day's error</div>
                              <div class="line">Have suffer'd wrong, go keep us company,</div>
                              <div class="line">And we shall make full satisfaction.</div>
                              <div class="line">Thirty-three years have I but gone in travail</div>
                              <div class="line">Of you, my sons; and till this present hour</div>
                              <div class="line">My heavy burden ne'er delivered.</div>
                              <div class="line">The duke, my husband and my children both,</div>
                              <div class="line">And you the calendars of their nativity,</div>
                              <div class="line">Go to a gossips' feast and go with me;</div>
                              <div class="line">After so long grief, such festivity!</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DUKE SOLINUS</div>
                              <div class="line">With all my heart, I'll gossip at this feast.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>Exeunt all but Antipholus of Syracuse, Antipholus
of Ephesus, Dromio of Syracuse and Dromio of Ephesus</p>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">Master, shall I fetch your stuff from shipboard?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Dromio, what stuff of mine hast thou embark'd?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">Your goods that lay at host, sir, in the Centaur.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">He speaks to me. I am your master, Dromio:</div>
                              <div class="line">Come, go with us; we'll look to that anon:</div>
                              <div class="line">Embrace thy brother there; rejoice with him.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Antipholus of Ephesus</p>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">There is a fat friend at your master's house,</div>
                              <div class="line">That kitchen'd me for you to-day at dinner:</div>
                              <div class="line">She now shall be my sister, not my wife.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Methinks you are my glass, and not my brother:</div>
                              <div class="line">I see by you I am a sweet-faced youth.</div>
                              <div class="line">Will you walk in to see their gossiping?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">Not I, sir; you are my elder.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">That's a question: how shall we try it?</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF SYRACUSE</div>
                              <div class="line">We'll draw cuts for the senior: till then lead thou first.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="dialogue">
                           <div class="linegroup">
                              <div class="speaker">DROMIO OF EPHESUS</div>
                              <div class="line">Nay, then, thus:</div>
                              <div class="line">We came into the world like brother and brother;</div>
                              <div class="line">And now let's go hand in hand, not one before another.</div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>Exeunt</p>
                     </div>
                  </section>
               </div>
            </article>
         </div>
      </article>

   </body>
</html>
The “current” CSS styling is applied to the this entire document; the results in this column may be anomalous. Also, image links are broken in this column. 

The Comedy of Errors

Table of Contents

  • 1. Dramatis Personae
  • 1. ACT I
    • 1. SCENE I. A hall in DUKE SOLINUS'S palace.
    • 2. SCENE II. The Mart.
  • 2. ACT II
    • 1. SCENE I. The house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.
    • 2. SCENE II. A public place.
  • 3. ACT III
    • 1. SCENE I. Before the house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.
    • 2. SCENE II. The same.
  • 4. ACT IV
    • 1. SCENE I. A public place.
    • 2. SCENE II. The house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.
    • 3. SCENE III. A public place.
    • 4. SCENE IV. A street.
  • 5. ACT V
    • 1. SCENE I. A street before a Priory.

Dramatis Personae

SOLINUS, Duke of Ephesus.

AEGEON, a merchant of Syracuse.

ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE twin brothers, and sons to Aegeon and Aemilia.
DROMIO OF EPHESUS DROMIO OF SYRACUSE twin brothers, and attendants on the two Antipholuses.

BALTHAZAR, a merchant

ANGELO, a goldsmith.

First Merchant, friend to Antipholus of Syracuse.

Second Merchant, to whom Angelo is a debtor.

PINCH, a schoolmaster.

AEMILIA, wife to Aegeon, an abbess at Ephesus.

ADRIANA, wife to Antipholus of Ephesus.

LUCIANA, her sister.

LUCE, servant to Adriana.

A Courtezan.

Gaoler, Officers, and other Attendants

SCENE Ephesus.

Chapter 1. ACT I

Table of Contents

  • 1. SCENE I. A hall in DUKE SOLINUS'S palace.
  • 2. SCENE II. The Mart.

1. SCENE I. A hall in DUKE SOLINUS'S palace.

Enter DUKE SOLINUS, AEGEON, Gaoler, Officers, and other Attendants

AEGEON
Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall
And by the doom of death end woes and all.
DUKE SOLINUS
Merchant of Syracuse, plead no more;
I am not partial to infringe our laws:
The enmity and discord which of late
Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your duke
To merchants, our well-dealing countrymen,
Who wanting guilders to redeem their lives
Have seal'd his rigorous statutes with their bloods,
Excludes all pity from our threatening looks.
For, since the mortal and intestine jars
'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us,
It hath in solemn synods been decreed
Both by the Syracusians and ourselves,
To admit no traffic to our adverse towns Nay, more,
If any born at Ephesus be seen
At any Syracusian marts and fairs;
Again: if any Syracusian born
Come to the bay of Ephesus, he dies,
His goods confiscate to the duke's dispose,
Unless a thousand marks be levied,
To quit the penalty and to ransom him.
Thy substance, valued at the highest rate,
Cannot amount unto a hundred marks;
Therefore by law thou art condemned to die.
AEGEON
Yet this my comfort: when your words are done,
My woes end likewise with the evening sun.
DUKE SOLINUS
Well, Syracusian, say in brief the cause
Why thou departed'st from thy native home
And for what cause thou camest to Ephesus.
AEGEON
A heavier task could not have been imposed
Than I to speak my griefs unspeakable:
Yet, that the world may witness that my end
Was wrought by nature, not by vile offence,
I'll utter what my sorrows give me leave.
In Syracusa was I born, and wed
Unto a woman, happy but for me,
And by me, had not our hap been bad.
With her I lived in joy; our wealth increased
By prosperous voyages I often made
To Epidamnum; till my factor's death
And the great care of goods at random left
Drew me from kind embracements of my spouse:
From whom my absence was not six months old
Before herself, almost at fainting under
The pleasing punishment that women bear,
Had made provision for her following me
And soon and safe arrived where I was.
There had she not been long, but she became
A joyful mother of two goodly sons;
And, which was strange, the one so like the other,
As could not be distinguish'd but by names.
That very hour, and in the self-same inn,
A meaner woman was delivered
Of such a burden, male twins, both alike:
Those,--for their parents were exceeding poor,--
I bought and brought up to attend my sons.
My wife, not meanly proud of two such boys,
Made daily motions for our home return:
Unwilling I agreed. Alas! too soon,
We came aboard.
A league from Epidamnum had we sail'd,
Before the always wind-obeying deep
Gave any tragic instance of our harm:
But longer did we not retain much hope;
For what obscured light the heavens did grant
Did but convey unto our fearful minds
A doubtful warrant of immediate death;
Which though myself would gladly have embraced,
Yet the incessant weepings of my wife,
Weeping before for what she saw must come,
And piteous plainings of the pretty babes,
That mourn'd for fashion, ignorant what to fear,
Forced me to seek delays for them and me.
And this it was, for other means was none:
The sailors sought for safety by our boat,
And left the ship, then sinking-ripe, to us:
My wife, more careful for the latter-born,
Had fasten'd him unto a small spare mast,
Such as seafaring men provide for storms;
To him one of the other twins was bound,
Whilst I had been like heedful of the other:
The children thus disposed, my wife and I,
Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fix'd,
Fasten'd ourselves at either end the mast;
And floating straight, obedient to the stream,
Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought.
At length the sun, gazing upon the earth,
Dispersed those vapours that offended us;
And by the benefit of his wished light,
The seas wax'd calm, and we discovered
Two ships from far making amain to us,
Of Corinth that, of Epidaurus this:
But ere they came,--O, let me say no more!
Gather the sequel by that went before.
DUKE SOLINUS
Nay, forward, old man; do not break off so;
For we may pity, though not pardon thee.
AEGEON
O, had the gods done so, I had not now
Worthily term'd them merciless to us!
For, ere the ships could meet by twice five leagues,
We were encounterd by a mighty rock;
Which being violently borne upon,
Our helpful ship was splitted in the midst;
So that, in this unjust divorce of us,
Fortune had left to both of us alike
What to delight in, what to sorrow for.
Her part, poor soul! seeming as burdened
With lesser weight but not with lesser woe,
Was carried with more speed before the wind;
And in our sight they three were taken up
By fishermen of Corinth, as we thought.
At length, another ship had seized on us;
And, knowing whom it was their hap to save,
Gave healthful welcome to their shipwreck'd guests;
And would have reft the fishers of their prey,
Had not their bark been very slow of sail;
And therefore homeward did they bend their course.
Thus have you heard me sever'd from my bliss;
That by misfortunes was my life prolong'd,
To tell sad stories of my own mishaps.
DUKE SOLINUS
And for the sake of them thou sorrowest for,
Do me the favour to dilate at full
What hath befall'n of them and thee till now.
AEGEON
My youngest boy, and yet my eldest care,
At eighteen years became inquisitive
After his brother: and importuned me
That his attendant--so his case was like,
Reft of his brother, but retain'd his name--
Might bear him company in the quest of him:
Whom whilst I labour'd of a love to see,
I hazarded the loss of whom I loved.
Five summers have I spent in furthest Greece,
Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia,
And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus;
Hopeless to find, yet loath to leave unsought
Or that or any place that harbours men.
But here must end the story of my life;
And happy were I in my timely death,
Could all my travels warrant me they live.
DUKE SOLINUS
Hapless AEgeon, whom the fates have mark'd
To bear the extremity of dire mishap!
Now, trust me, were it not against our laws,
Against my crown, my oath, my dignity,
Which princes, would they, may not disannul,
My soul would sue as advocate for thee.
But, though thou art adjudged to the death
And passed sentence may not be recall'd
But to our honour's great disparagement,
Yet I will favour thee in what I can.
Therefore, merchant, I'll limit thee this day
To seek thy life by beneficial help:
Try all the friends thou hast in Ephesus;
Beg thou, or borrow, to make up the sum,
And live; if no, then thou art doom'd to die.
Gaoler, take him to thy custody.
Gaoler
I will, my lord.
AEGEON
Hopeless and helpless doth AEgeon wend,
But to procrastinate his lifeless end.

Exeunt

2. SCENE II. The Mart.

Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse, DROMIO of Syracuse, and First Merchant

First Merchant
Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum,
Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate.
This very day a Syracusian merchant
Is apprehended for arrival here;
And not being able to buy out his life
According to the statute of the town,
Dies ere the weary sun set in the west.
There is your money that I had to keep.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Go bear it to the Centaur, where we host,
And stay there, Dromio, till I come to thee.
Within this hour it will be dinner-time:
Till that, I'll view the manners of the town,
Peruse the traders, gaze upon the buildings,
And then return and sleep within mine inn,
For with long travel I am stiff and weary.
Get thee away.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Many a man would take you at your word,
And go indeed, having so good a mean.

Exit

ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
A trusty villain, sir, that very oft,
When I am dull with care and melancholy,
Lightens my humour with his merry jests.
What, will you walk with me about the town,
And then go to my inn and dine with me?
First Merchant
I am invited, sir, to certain merchants,
Of whom I hope to make much benefit;
I crave your pardon. Soon at five o'clock,
Please you, I'll meet with you upon the mart
And afterward consort you till bed-time:
My present business calls me from you now.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Farewell till then: I will go lose myself
And wander up and down to view the city.
First Merchant
Sir, I commend you to your own content.

Exit

ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
He that commends me to mine own content
Commends me to the thing I cannot get.
I to the world am like a drop of water
That in the ocean seeks another drop,
Who, falling there to find his fellow forth,
Unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself:
So I, to find a mother and a brother,
In quest of them, unhappy, lose myself.

Enter DROMIO of Ephesus

Here comes the almanac of my true date.
What now? how chance thou art return'd so soon?
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
Return'd so soon! rather approach'd too late:
The capon burns, the pig falls from the spit,
The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bell;
My mistress made it one upon my cheek:
She is so hot because the meat is cold;
The meat is cold because you come not home;
You come not home because you have no stomach;
You have no stomach having broke your fast;
But we that know what 'tis to fast and pray
Are penitent for your default to-day.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Stop in your wind, sir: tell me this, I pray:
Where have you left the money that I gave you?
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
O,--sixpence, that I had o' Wednesday last
To pay the saddler for my mistress' crupper?
The saddler had it, sir; I kept it not.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
I am not in a sportive humour now:
Tell me, and dally not, where is the money?
We being strangers here, how darest thou trust
So great a charge from thine own custody?
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
I pray you, air, as you sit at dinner:
I from my mistress come to you in post;
If I return, I shall be post indeed,
For she will score your fault upon my pate.
Methinks your maw, like mine, should be your clock,
And strike you home without a messenger.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Come, Dromio, come, these jests are out of season;
Reserve them till a merrier hour than this.
Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee?
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
To me, sir? why, you gave no gold to me.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Come on, sir knave, have done your foolishness,
And tell me how thou hast disposed thy charge.
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
My charge was but to fetch you from the mart
Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner:
My mistress and her sister stays for you.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
In what safe place you have bestow'd my money,
Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours
That stands on tricks when I am undisposed:
Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me?
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
I have some marks of yours upon my pate,
Some of my mistress' marks upon my shoulders,
But not a thousand marks between you both.
If I should pay your worship those again,
Perchance you will not bear them patiently.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Thy mistress' marks? what mistress, slave, hast thou?
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
Your worship's wife, my mistress at the Phoenix;
She that doth fast till you come home to dinner,
And prays that you will hie you home to dinner.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
What, wilt thou flout me thus unto my face,
Being forbid? There, take you that, sir knave.
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
What mean you, sir? for God's sake, hold your hands!
Nay, and you will not, sir, I'll take my heels.

Exit

ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Upon my life, by some device or other
The villain is o'er-raught of all my money.
They say this town is full of cozenage,
As, nimble jugglers that deceive the eye,
Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind,
Soul-killing witches that deform the body,
Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks,
And many such-like liberties of sin:
If it prove so, I will be gone the sooner.
I'll to the Centaur, to go seek this slave:
I greatly fear my money is not safe.

Exit

Chapter 2. ACT II

Table of Contents

  • 1. SCENE I. The house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.
  • 2. SCENE II. A public place.

1. SCENE I. The house of ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus.

Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA

ADRIANA
Neither my husband nor the slave return'd,
That in such haste I sent to seek his master!
Sure, Luciana, it is two o'clock.
LUCIANA
Perhaps some merchant hath invited him,
And from the mart he's somewhere gone to dinner.
Good sister, let us dine and never fret:
A man is master of his liberty:
Time is their master, and, when they see time,
They'll go or come: if so, be patient, sister.
ADRIANA
Why should their liberty than ours be more?
LUCIANA
Because their business still lies out o' door.
ADRIANA
Look, when I serve him so, he takes it ill.
LUCIANA
O, know he is the bridle of your will.
ADRIANA
There's none but asses will be bridled so.
LUCIANA
Why, headstrong liberty is lash'd with woe.
There's nothing situate under heaven's eye
But hath his bound, in earth, in sea, in sky:
The beasts, the fishes, and the winged fowls,
Are their males' subjects and at their controls:
Men, more divine, the masters of all these,
Lords of the wide world and wild watery seas,
Indued with intellectual sense and souls,
Of more preeminence than fish and fowls,
Are masters to their females, and their lords:
Then let your will attend on their accords.
ADRIANA
This servitude makes you to keep unwed.
LUCIANA
Not this, but troubles of the marriage-bed.
ADRIANA
But, were you wedded, you would bear some sway.
LUCIANA
Ere I learn love, I'll practise to obey.
ADRIANA
How if your husband start some other where?
LUCIANA
Till he come home again, I would forbear.
ADRIANA
Patience unmoved! no marvel though she pause;
They can be meek that have no other cause.
A wretched soul, bruised with adversity,
We bid be quiet when we hear it cry;
But were we burdened with like weight of pain,
As much or more would we ourselves complain:
So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee,
With urging helpless patience wouldst relieve me,
But, if thou live to see like right bereft,
This fool-begg'd patience in thee will be left.
LUCIANA
Well, I will marry one day, but to try.
Here comes your man; now is your husband nigh.

Enter DROMIO of Ephesus

ADRIANA
Say, is your tardy master now at hand?
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
Nay, he's at two hands with me, and that my two ears
can witness.
ADRIANA
Say, didst thou speak with him? know'st thou his mind?
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
Ay, ay, he told his mind upon mine ear:
Beshrew his hand, I scarce could understand it.
LUCIANA
Spake he so doubtfully, thou couldst not feel his meaning?
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
Nay, he struck so plainly, I could too well feel his
blows; and withal so doubtfully that I could scarce
understand them.
ADRIANA
But say, I prithee, is he coming home? It seems he
hath great care to please his wife.
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
Why, mistress, sure my master is horn-mad.
ADRIANA
Horn-mad, thou villain!
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
I mean not cuckold-mad;
But, sure, he is stark mad.
When I desired him to come home to dinner,
He ask'd me for a thousand marks in gold:
''Tis dinner-time,' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he;
'Your meat doth burn,' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he:
'Will you come home?' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he.
'Where is the thousand marks I gave thee, villain?'
'The pig,' quoth I, 'is burn'd;' 'My gold!' quoth he:
'My mistress, sir' quoth I; 'Hang up thy mistress!
I know not thy mistress; out on thy mistress!'
LUCIANA
Quoth who?
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
Quoth my master:
'I know,' quoth he, 'no house, no wife, no mistress.'
So that my errand, due unto my tongue,
I thank him, I bare home upon my shoulders;
For, in conclusion, he did beat me there.
ADRIANA
Go back again, thou slave, and fetch him home.
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
Go back again, and be new beaten home?
For God's sake, send some other messenger.
ADRIANA
Back, slave, or I will break thy pate across.
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
And he will bless that cross with other beating:
Between you I shall have a holy head.
ADRIANA
Hence, prating peasant! fetch thy master home.
DROMIO OF EPHESUS
Am I so round with you as you with me,
That like a football you do spurn me thus?
You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither:
If I last in this service, you must case me in leather.

Exit

LUCIANA
Fie, how impatience loureth in your face!
ADRIANA
His company must do his minions grace,
Whilst I at home starve for a merry look.
Hath homely age the alluring beauty took
From my poor cheek? then he hath wasted it:
Are my discourses dull? barren my wit?
If voluble and sharp discourse be marr'd,
Unkindness blunts it more than marble hard:
Do their gay vestments his affections bait?
That's not my fault: he's master of my state:
What ruins are in me that can be found,
By him not ruin'd? then is he the ground
Of my defeatures. My decayed fair
A sunny look of his would soon repair
But, too unruly deer, he breaks the pale
And feeds from home; poor I am but his stale.
LUCIANA
Self-harming jealousy! fie, beat it hence!
ADRIANA
Unfeeling fools can with such wrongs dispense.
I know his eye doth homage otherwhere,
Or else what lets it but he would be here?
Sister, you know he promised me a chain;
Would that alone, alone he would detain,
So he would keep fair quarter with his bed!
I see the jewel best enamelled
Will lose his beauty; yet the gold bides still,
That others touch, and often touching will
Wear gold: and no man that hath a name,
By falsehood and corruption doth it shame.
Since that my beauty cannot please his eye,
I'll weep what's left away, and weeping die.
LUCIANA
How many fond fools serve mad jealousy!

Exeunt

2. SCENE II. A public place.

Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse

ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up
Safe at the Centaur; and the heedful slave
Is wander'd forth, in care to seek me out
By computation and mine host's report.
I could not speak with Dromio since at first
I sent him from the mart. See, here he comes.

Enter DROMIO of Syracuse

How now sir! is your merry humour alter'd?
As you love strokes, so jest with me again.
You know no Centaur? you received no gold?
Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner?
My house was at the Phoenix? Wast thou mad,
That thus so madly thou didst answer me?
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
What answer, sir? when spake I such a word?
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Even now, even here, not half an hour since.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
I did not see you since you sent me hence,
Home to the Centaur, with the gold you gave me.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Villain, thou didst deny the gold's receipt,
And told'st me of a mistress and a dinner;
For which, I hope, thou felt'st I was displeased.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
I am glad to see you in this merry vein:
What means this jest? I pray you, master, tell me.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Yea, dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth?
Think'st thou I jest? Hold, take thou that, and that.

Beating him

DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Hold, sir, for God's sake! now your jest is earnest:
Upon what bargain do you give it me?
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Because that I familiarly sometimes
Do use you for my fool and chat with you,
Your sauciness will jest upon my love
And make a common of my serious hours.
When the sun shines let foolish gnats make sport,
But creep in crannies when he hides his beams.
If you will jest with me, know my aspect,
And fashion your demeanor to my looks,
Or I will beat this method in your sconce.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Sconce call you it? so you would leave battering, I
had rather have it a head: an you use these blows
long, I must get a sconce for my head and ensconce
it too; or else I shall seek my wit in my shoulders.
But, I pray, sir why am I beaten?
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Dost thou not know?
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Nothing, sir, but that I am beaten.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Shall I tell you why?
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Ay, sir, and wherefore; for they say every why hath
a wherefore.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Why, first,--for flouting me; and then, wherefore--
For urging it the second time to me.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Was there ever any man thus beaten out of season,
When in the why and the wherefore is neither rhyme
nor reason?
Well, sir, I thank you.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Thank me, sir, for what?
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Marry, sir, for this something that you gave me for nothing.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
I'll make you amends next, to give you nothing for
something. But say, sir, is it dinner-time?
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
No, sir; I think the meat wants that I have.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
In good time, sir; what's that?
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Basting.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Well, sir, then 'twill be dry.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
If it be, sir, I pray you, eat none of it.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Your reason?
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Lest it make you choleric and purchase me another
dry basting.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Well, sir, learn to jest in good time: there's a
time for all things.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
I durst have denied that, before you were so choleric.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
By what rule, sir?
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald
pate of father Time himself.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Let's hear it.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
There's no time for a man to recover his hair that
grows bald by nature.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
May he not do it by fine and recovery?
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Yes, to pay a fine for a periwig and recover the
lost hair of another man.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Why is Time such a niggard of hair, being, as it is,
so plentiful an excrement?
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Because it is a blessing that he bestows on beasts;
and what he hath scanted men in hair he hath given them in wit.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Why, but there's many a man hath more hair than wit.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Not a man of those but he hath the wit to lose his hair.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Why, thou didst conclude hairy men plain dealers without wit.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
The plainer dealer, the sooner lost: yet he loseth
it in a kind of jollity.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
For what reason?
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
For two; and sound ones too.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Nay, not sound, I pray you.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Sure ones, then.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Nay, not sure, in a thing falsing.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Certain ones then.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
Name them.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
The one, to save the money that he spends in
trimming; the other, that at dinner they should not
drop in his porridge.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
You would all this time have proved there is no
time for all things.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Marry, and did, sir; namely, no time to recover hair
lost by nature.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
But your reason was not substantial, why there is no
time to recover.
DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald and therefore
to the world's end will have bald followers.
ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
I knew 'twould be a bald conclusion:
But, soft! who wafts us yonder?

Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA

ADRIANA
Ay, ay, Antipholus, look strange and frown:
Some other mistress hath thy sweet aspects;
I am not Adriana nor thy wife.
The time was once when thou unurged wouldst vow
